summary: This is a letter from U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta to retired Judge Edward B. Davis, appointing him as a Special Master to select an attorney representative for identified victims in the Jeffrey Epstein case. It outlines the terms of Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement regarding victim compensation and provides criteria for selecting the victims' attorney.

persons.name: Edward B. Davis
persons.context: Retired judge appointed by the U.S. Attorney's Office to consult with and select an attorney representative for the identified victims in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of a federal investigation who entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office, agreeing to pay for a victims' attorney representative and waiving certain defenses in potential civil suits under 18 U.S.C. § 2255.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who signed the letter appointing the Special Master and outlining the victim representation process under the Epstein agreement.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, formally appoints Davis as a Special Master to select an attorney for Epstein's victims.
Epstein entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office led by Acosta, which included provisions for victim compensation.

Davis, as Special Master, is tasked with selecting a victims' attorney representative, a role created by the agreement between Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office. Epstein's counsel retains a right of good faith objection to the selection.

events.title: Appointment of Special Master for Victim Representation
events.description: U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta formally appoints retired Judge Edward B. Davis as a Special Master to select an attorney to represent identified victims of Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Execution of Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office enter into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) that includes provisions for Epstein to pay for a victims' attorney representative and outlines waivers of defenses in potential civil suits filed by victims under 18 U.S.C. § 2255.

keyFacts: The document confirms the existence of a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, led by R. Alexander Acosta.

The NPA includes a mechanism where an independent third-party (Special Master) selects an attorney to represent identified victims, with Epstein agreeing to pay that attorney's fees, unless the victim files contested litigation.

Epstein agreed to waive jurisdictional defenses and not contest liability or damages (up to an agreed amount) in civil suits brought under 18 U.S.C. § 2255 by identified victims, provided they waive all other claims.

The U.S. Attorney's Office had identified victims, defined as minors victimized under statutes 18 U.S.C. §§ 2422 or 2423, who were between the ages of 16 and 24 at the time of the letter (October 2007).

The letter outlines specific criteria for the victims' attorney representative, including experience in federal litigation, sensitivity to victim privacy, and the ability to negotiate effectively or prepare for trial.
